label: RSI
blurb: Momentum oscillator scaled 0–100; useful for momentum filters and reversal signals.
longSummary: RSI compares average gains to losses over N periods and outputs a value from 0 to 100. Above a chosen threshold (e.g., 55–60) often reflects bullish momentum; below a threshold (e.g., 40–45) reflects bearish pressure. RSI is most reliable when aligned with the broader regime (e.g., a trend filter) and when avoiding major news spikes. Common use cases: momentum breakout, pullback continuation, and mean-reversion bounce.
mathSummary: RSI = 100 − 100 / (1 + RS), where RS = AvgGain / AvgLoss (smoothed).

tooltips._indicator: RSI measures momentum on a 0–100 scale.
tooltips.source: Price source used to compute RSI.
tooltips.obLevel: Common overbought ~70; momentum filters often use 55–60.
tooltips.osLevel: Common oversold ~30; bearish filters often use 40–45.
